articles.headline: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop
articles.snippet: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.
articles.abstract: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The ordinary looking office building in a suburb of Baltimore gives no hint of the high-tech detective work going on inside. A $100 million system churns through complicated medical claims, searching for suspicious patterns and posting the findings on a giant screen.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Resisting Nazis, He Saw Need for Israel. Now He Is Its Critic.
articles.snippet: Henk Zanoli, 91, who saved a Jewish boy in 1943, said he could not keep the award he received from Israel after six relatives of his grandniece’s Palestinian husband were killed in Gaza last month.
articles.abstract: Henk Zanoli, 91, who saved a Jewish boy in 1943, said he could not keep the award he received from Israel after six relatives of his grandniece’s Palestinian husband were killed in Gaza last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — In 1943, Henk Zanoli took a dangerous train trip, slipping past Nazi guards and checkpoints to smuggle a Jewish boy from Amsterdam to the Dutch village of Eemnes. There, the Zanoli family, already under suspicion for resisting the Nazi occupation, hid the boy in their home for two years. The boy would be the only member of his family to survive the Holocaust.
articles.byline: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas Is Indicted on Charge of Abuse of Power
articles.snippet: A grand jury indicted the governor of Texas on two felony counts in an investigation examining his handling of a local district attorney’s drunken driving arrest and the state financing for a public corruption unit under the lawyer’s control.
articles.abstract: A grand jury indicted the governor of Texas on two felony counts in an investigation examining his handling of a local district attorney’s drunken driving arrest and the state financing for a public corruption unit under the lawyer’s control.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A grand jury indicted Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts on Friday, charging that he abused his power last year when he tried to pressure the district attorney here, a Democrat, to step down by threatening to cut off state financing to her office.

articles.headline: For Its New Shows, Amazon Adds Art to Its Data
articles.snippet: After an underwhelming initial foray into making its own video programming, Amazon has poured even more money into the effort.
articles.abstract: After an underwhelming initial foray into making its own video programming, Amazon has poured even more money into the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Joe Lewis, a television executive at Amazon, lies on his stomach on a rumpled bed. Jill Soloway, the Emmy-nominated writer and director, sits next to him, stroking the back of his head. The two stare at a pair of monitors, watching the filming of a scene in the next room from their new dark comedy about a family in which the father comes out as transgender.

articles.headline: As World Boils, Fingers Point Obama’s Way
articles.snippet: Buffeted by international instability, the president stresses that there are limits to American power, and that the chief executive is not omnipotent.
articles.abstract: Buffeted by international instability, the president stresses that there are limits to American power, and that the chief executive is not omnipotent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In this summer of global tumult, the debate in Washington essentially boils down to two opposite positions: It is all President Obama’s fault, according to his critics; no, it is not, according to his supporters, because these are events beyond his control.

articles.headline: Midnight Curfew in Effect for Ferguson
articles.snippet: Gov. Jay Nixon ordered the curfew as protests continued over the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, and after incidents of looting Friday night.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon ordered the curfew as protests continued over the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, and after incidents of looting Friday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri on Saturday imposed a midnight to 5 a.m. curfew in this small city, declaring a state of emergency as violence flared anew after a week of street protests over the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: In a Bank Settlement, Don’t Forget the Bulldozers
articles.snippet: If it provides hard cash for demolishing abandoned homes, an impending settlement by Bank of America could help many forgotten victims of the mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: If it provides hard cash for demolishing abandoned homes, an impending settlement by Bank of America could help many forgotten victims of the mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: A win-win. That’s how people on both sides of the negotiating table will undoubtedly characterize the long-awaited, $16 billion-plus mortgage settlement that Bank of America is expected to reach with the Justice Department this week. For federal and state governments, the deal will mean billions in cash and borrower assistance. For the bank, the agreement will help it get past its mortgage woes, many emanating from its 2008 purchase of Countrywide Financial, a truly toxic lender.

articles.headline: Authenticity, Repurposed, in a Mason Jar
articles.snippet: The simple and sturdy Mason jar, a 19th-century staple, has been embraced by companies trying to reach a new generation of consumers.
articles.abstract: The simple and sturdy Mason jar, a 19th-century staple, has been embraced by companies trying to reach a new generation of consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve sipped a beer from a Mason jar. Or fished out a pickle swimming in brine from one. Or dined under illuminated clusters of them, dangling in chandelier formation, at a restaurant — especially if you dined in Brooklyn.

articles.headline: In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty
articles.snippet: Workers are their own bosses in the so-called sharing economy, but that flexibility also brings much uncertainty — and few of the protections of full-time work.
articles.abstract: Workers are their own bosses in the so-called sharing economy, but that flexibility also brings much uncertainty — and few of the protections of full-time work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just after 4 a.m. on a recent Friday, while most of the neighbors in her leafy Boston suburb were still asleep, Jennifer Guidry was in the driveway of her rental apartment, her blond hair pulled back in a tidy French braid, vacuuming the inside of her car. The early-bird routine is a strategy that Ms. Guidry, a Navy veteran and former accountant, uses to mitigate the uncertainty of working in what’s known as the sharing economy.

articles.headline: Lassie as Salesdog: One More Trip to the Well
articles.snippet: Lassie’s new owners at DreamWorks Animation are using a series of publicity stunts to remake the classic American dog as a merchandising superstar.
articles.abstract: Lassie’s new owners at DreamWorks Animation are using a series of publicity stunts to remake the classic American dog as a merchandising superstar.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Maybe it was the three publicists in tow. Maybe her hairdo was wilting under the hot television lights. Maybe a dog, even a showbiz one, was just not meant to be a meteorologist.

articles.headline: Deep Tensions Rise to Surface After Ferguson Shooting
articles.snippet: The origins of Ferguson’s complex racial history run deep, and the residents of the largely black city with a white power structure say that most tensions have to do with an overzealous police force.
articles.abstract: The origins of Ferguson’s complex racial history run deep, and the residents of the largely black city with a white power structure say that most tensions have to do with an overzealous police force.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Garland Moore, a hospital worker, lived in this St. Louis suburb for much of his 33 years, a period in which a largely white community has become a largely black one.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and John Eligon

articles.headline: With Aid Doctors Gone, Ebola Fight Grows Harder
articles.snippet: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the region’s decrepit, understaffed health systems.
articles.abstract: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the region’s decrepit, understaffed health systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: When people started dying of Ebola in Liberia, Clarine Vaughn faced a wrenching choice: Should she send home, for their own health and safety, four American doctors working for Heartt, the aid group she led there? Or should she keep them in the country without proper supplies or training to fight the virulent, contagious disease, which was already spreading panic?

articles.headline: On a Helicopter, Going Down: Inside a Lethal Crash in Iraq
articles.snippet: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated this article from her hospital bed in Istanbul.
articles.abstract: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated this article from her hospital bed in Istanbul.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured on Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated the following article from her hospital bed in Istanbul, where she was evacuated from Iraq. She suffered broken bones and a fractured skull but was in stable condition, and was scheduled to be taken by air to the United States on Sunday.

articles.headline: Transplant Brokers in Israel Lure Desperate Kidney Patients to Costa Rica
articles.snippet: Facing the prospect of impossibly long waiting lists for organs, some patients have turned to an underground trade that pairs them with people willing to sell an organ.
articles.abstract: Facing the prospect of impossibly long waiting lists for organs, some patients have turned to an underground trade that pairs them with people willing to sell an organ.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMAT GAN, Israel — Aside from the six-figure price tag, what was striking was just how easy it was for Ophira Dorin to buy a kidney.

articles.headline: Violence Flares in Ferguson After Appeals for Harmony
articles.snippet: Despite efforts throughout the day in local churches to tamp down the outrage, the most chaotic violence in a week of unrest broke out in Ferguson, Mo., on Sunday night.
articles.abstract: Despite efforts throughout the day in local churches to tamp down the outrage, the most chaotic violence in a week of unrest broke out in Ferguson, Mo., on Sunday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Hours ahead of a second night of a mandatory curfew, the most chaotic violence in a week of unrest broke out here Sunday evening, with law enforcement officers facing off against angry protesters and responding to reports of gunfire and fire bombs.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: View of #Ferguson Thrust Michael Brown Shooting to National Attention
articles.snippet: In a situation hostile to traditional reporting, the crowdsourced, phone-enabled network of information that Twitter provides has proved invaluable.
articles.abstract: In a situation hostile to traditional reporting, the crowdsourced, phone-enabled network of information that Twitter provides has proved invaluable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ferguson, Missouri, was just a place — a working-class suburb of St. Louis — before an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, was shot and killed by the police, before protests and looting erupted, before local forces responded with armored vehicles, tear gas and rubber bullets, and Ferguson became #Ferguson.

articles.headline: Childhood Passion for Celebrity Still Drives the Editor of People Magazine, Jess Cagle
articles.snippet: For Mr. Cagle, who grew up a Hollywood-obsessed pop culture fanatic in Abilene, Tex., the goal is to turn his passion for celebrity into profits.
articles.abstract: For Mr. Cagle, who grew up a Hollywood-obsessed pop culture fanatic in Abilene, Tex., the goal is to turn his passion for celebrity into profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Monday, Jess Cagle, the new editor of People magazine, had just returned from a meeting in London with representatives of the royal family when he heard about Robin Williams’s death. He ripped up the coming cover on Kate Middleton and ordered a 12-page spread on the comedian.

articles.headline: Bank Overseer PwC Faces Penalty and Sidelining of Regulatory Consulting Unit
articles.snippet: PricewaterhouseCoopers is said to have agreed to pay a $25 million fine in New York for obscuring misconduct it was supposed to unearth.
articles.abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers is said to have agreed to pay a $25 million fine in New York for obscuring misconduct it was supposed to unearth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The giant consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers occupies a position of trust on Wall Street, acting as a shadow regulator of sorts that promises the government an impartial look inside the world’s biggest banks.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: In Torn Gaza, if Roof Stands, It’s Now Home
articles.snippet: With an estimated 11,000 homes destroyed and many more severely damaged, Gaza’s housing and humanitarian troubles are just beginning.
articles.abstract: With an estimated 11,000 homes destroyed and many more severely damaged, Gaza’s housing and humanitarian troubles are just beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Telltale signs of the displaced are everywhere in Gaza.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Mergers Must Meet the Toothbrush Test
articles.snippet: Companies like Google are employing unorthodox criteria — say, whether a product is used daily, like a toothbrush — to size up their deal targets, and without the advice of Wall Street bankers.
articles.abstract: Companies like Google are employing unorthodox criteria — say, whether a product is used daily, like a toothbrush — to size up their deal targets, and without the advice of Wall Street bankers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — When deciding whether Google should spend millions or even billions of dollars in acquiring a new company, its chief executive, Larry Page, asks whether the acquisition passes the toothbrush test: Is it something you will use once or twice a day, and does it make your life better?

articles.headline: Seeking New Start, Finding Steep Cost
articles.snippet: Millions of Americans have trained for new careers through the $3.1 billion Workforce Investment Act, but many have not found new jobs and are instead faced with thousands of dollars of debt.
articles.abstract: Millions of Americans have trained for new careers through the $3.1 billion Workforce Investment Act, but many have not found new jobs and are instead faced with thousands of dollars of debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When the financial crisis crippled the construction industry seven years ago, Joe DeGrella’s contracting company failed, leaving him looking for what he hoped would be the last job he would ever need.

articles.headline: Autopsy Shows Michael Brown Was Struck at Least 6 Times
articles.snippet: A private, family-requested autopsy shows that Michael Brown was shot at least six times — twice in the head — with all of the bullets striking him in the front.
articles.abstract: A private, family-requested autopsy shows that Michael Brown was shot at least six times — twice in the head — with all of the bullets striking him in the front.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Michael Brown, the unarmed black teenager who was killed by a police officer, sparking protests around the nation, was shot at least six times, including twice in the head, a preliminary private autopsy performed on Sunday found.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Missouri Tries Another Idea: Call In National Guard
articles.snippet: In the days since a teenager was shot to death in Ferguson, Mo., an array of state and local law enforcement authorities have swerved from one approach to another.
articles.abstract: In the days since a teenager was shot to death in Ferguson, Mo., an array of state and local law enforcement authorities have swerved from one approach to another.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Missouri National Guard troops entered this battered city on Monday even as an overnight curfew was lifted, the latest in a series of quickly shifting attempts to quell the violence that has upended this St. Louis suburb for more than a week.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey, John Eligon and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Rival Bids for Family Dollar Stores as Retailers Fight to Sell to Working Poor
articles.snippet: Dollar General offered to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, hoping to break up its fellow deep-discount retailer Family Tree’s agreed-upon $8.5 billion merger with Family Dollar.
articles.abstract: Dollar General offered to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, hoping to break up its fellow deep-discount retailer Family Tree’s agreed-upon $8.5 billion merger with Family Dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | As more struggling Americans hit the bargain bins to get by, a bidding war is brewing for one of the country’s biggest deep-discount retailers.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Troops in Iraq Rout Sunni Militants From a Key Dam
articles.snippet: Kurdish and Iraqi forces on Monday took control of the Mosul Dam with the help of U.S. airstrikes that seemed to expand President Obama’s limited goals in authorizing a military campaign in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Kurdish and Iraqi forces on Monday took control of the Mosul Dam with the help of U.S. airstrikes that seemed to expand President Obama’s limited goals in authorizing a military campaign in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iraqi and Kurdish ground troops overran Sunni militants and reclaimed Iraq’s largest dam on Monday, President Obama said, as American warplanes unleashed a barrage of bombs in an expansion of the limited goals laid out by the president in authorizing the military campaign in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Mark Landler and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Altered Bank Study Draws Fine for Giant Auditor PwC
articles.snippet: The fine is tied to a review PricewaterhouseCoopers did in 2007 for the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ of its transactions with Iran and other countries under sanctions.
articles.abstract: The fine is tied to a review PricewaterhouseCoopers did in 2007 for the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ of its transactions with Iran and other countries under sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York State’s financial regulator announced a settlement deal on Monday with the giant consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, capping an investigation into the firm’s cozy ties with one of the world’s biggest banks.
